moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6
comment: If Karpov wanted to make a point and try to win with Black against the 12-year old then this probably isn't the best try. However, it has been his opening of choice recently, so he's sticking to the it.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3
comment: Karjakin copies Shirov, who beat Karpov, and hopes for the same result. It will be interesting to see what improvement (s) Karpov has in mind.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8
comment: This small change doesn't necessarily mean much, though it does allow ...Nd7-f8 to keep Ph7 safer and to leave the queen-side pawns less blocked. Perhaps he'll advance on the queen-side this time.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6
comment: It's not exactly easy to criticize this move, but after Bc4-d3 then what is Nb6 doing? Does he intend to invade at c4 after ...Bc8-e6?

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5
comment: Now White has f4 for his queen, so ...f6 might be good, though it's not like Karpov to voluntarily weaken his king's position even for a useful tempo.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5
comment: Here come the pawns.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6
comment: Wow! Can this really be good?

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4
comment: Karpov forces a queen trade to gain equality, but with little hope of actually winning.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5
comment: Quickly, after the queen trade we're in an ending and Black's better pawns are good, but not nearly enough to convey an advantage. The opposite color bishops don't mean much at this point. If one side was to build up an attack it could be extra useful, but more likely the position will lead to simplifying rook trades and the bishops will make it even more drawish.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5 f6 22. Bc1 Kf7 23. Re3 b5 24. Rde1 h5 25. h4 Ra6 26. R3e2 Rc6 27. Bd2
comment: arriving at the better square anyway

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5 f6 22. Bc1 Kf7 23. Re3 b5 24. Rde1 h5 25. h4 Ra6 26. R3e2 Rc6 27. Bd2 Rc5 28. b3 Re5
comment: White's dominance of the e-file just evaporated!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5 f6 22. Bc1 Kf7 23. Re3 b5 24. Rde1 h5 25. h4 Ra6 26. R3e2 Rc6 27. Bd2 Rc5 28. b3 Re5 29. Bf4 Rxe2 30. Rxe2
comment: White has several weak spots (Pa2, Pc2, Pg2, Ph4) , but they're difficult for White to get to. Black has several weak spots also (Pa4, Pb5, Pc7 and Ph5) , but they're equally inacessible. Perhaps Pa4 is the most exposed for Black.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5 f6 22. Bc1 Kf7 23. Re3 b5 24. Rde1 h5 25. h4 Ra6 26. R3e2 Rc6 27. Bd2 Rc5 28. b3 Re5 29. Bf4 Rxe2 30. Rxe2 Ra8
comment: defending the weakest spot

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5 f6 22. Bc1 Kf7 23. Re3 b5 24. Rde1 h5 25. h4 Ra6 26. R3e2 Rc6 27. Bd2 Rc5 28. b3 Re5 29. Bf4 Rxe2 30. Rxe2 Ra8 31. Kb2 Bd5
comment: preventing Re2-e4

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5 f6 22. Bc1 Kf7 23. Re3 b5 24. Rde1 h5 25. h4 Ra6 26. R3e2 Rc6 27. Bd2 Rc5 28. b3 Re5 29. Bf4 Rxe2 30. Rxe2 Ra8 31. Kb2 Bd5 32. Bg3 Bc6 33. Be1 g5 34. Kc1
comment: White won't capture Pg5 because hxg5 ...fxg5 gives Black a better chance to produce a passed h-file pawn. Similarly, Black won't capture Pb3 because ...axb3 and cxb3 gives White a chance to produce an a-file passed pawn by a2-a4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Be1 g5 34. Kc1 Rg8 35. Kd2 Bd7 36. Ke3 Bf5
comment: threatening ...Rd8+ to trade rooks and then win Pc2

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Bf6 Qb5 18. Bxc4 Qxc4 19. Qg5 Qg4 20. f3 Qxg5 21. Bxg5 f6 22. Bc1 Kf7 23. Re3 b5 24. Rde1 h5 25. h4 Ra6 26. R3e2 Rc6 27. Bd2 Rc5 28. b3 Re5 29. Bf4 Rxe2 30. Rxe2 Ra8 31. Kb2 Bd5 32. Bg3 Bc6 33. Be1 g5 34. Kc1 Rg8 35. Kd2 Bd7 36. Ke3 Bf5 37. Kd2 Be6 38. Bf2 Ke7 39. Bg3 Kd7 40. Bf2 g4 41. Ke3 gxf3 42. gxf3 c5 43. Kf4 Rg2 44. Rd2 Kc6 45. Be3 Rg8
comment: Black's rook can't get to the eighth rank to swing around and get at Pa2 or Ph4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. Nc3 Nxc3 6. dxc3 Be7 7. Bf4 O-O 8. Qd2 Nd7 9. O-O-O Re8 10. Bc4 Nb6 11. Bd3 Be6 12. Ng5 Bxg5 13. Bxg5 Qd7 14. Kb1 Nc4 15. Qc1 a5 16. Rhe1 a4 17. Be1 g5 34. Kc1 Rg8 35. Kd2 Bd7 36. Ke3 Bf5 37. Kd2 Be6 38. Bf2 Ke7 39. Bg3 Kd7 40. Bf2 g4 41. Ke3 gxf3 42. gxf3 c5 43. Kf4 Rg2 44. Rd2 Kc6 45. Be3 Rg8 46. Rd1 Bf7 47. Rd2 Re8
comment: This is an interesting example of the old axiom that whomever is attacking with opposite-color bishops has, in effect, an extra piece; because the attacking bishop isn't so easily opposed.

Bd2 Be6 50. Rf2 Bg8 51. Be3 Bh7 52. Rd2 Rf5+ 53. Kg3 Rd5
comment: Black has found a way to force a rook trade when Pc2 will fall. Be3 and Kg3 look like spectators at this point.

Kd2 Bg2 66. Be7 d4 67. cxd4 cxd4 68. Bd6 Kd5 69. Be7 Ke4 70. Bg5 Bf1 71. Bh6 Bb5 72. Bg5 Kf3 73. Bh6 Kg3 74. Bg5 Kg4 75. Ke1
comment: Black's Bb5 and Pd4 can't beat Ke1 and Black's Kg4 can't beat White's Bg5 and pawns. But, mostly Black can't force White's king away, so Kg4 can quickly sweep in and assist Pd4 to advance further.
